newsitem.title: USA: Mobil, Chevron report strong earnings; Phillips net drops.
newsitem.headline: Mobil, Chevron report strong earnings; Phillips net drops.

text.p: Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. reported higher-than-expected earnings Wednesday due to strong gains in oil prices, while Phillips Petroleum Co.'s profits fell.
Mobil said its operating earnings rose 12 percent to $826.0 million or $2.11 a share vs. year-earlier earnings of $736.0 million or $1.83 a share.
Revenues fell to $16.18 billion from $18.69 billion a year earlier as a result of its refining and marketing alliance with British Petroleum in Europe, the company said.
The Fairfax, Va.-based company said its results were boosted by higher crude oil and natural gas prices.
Average U.S. crude oil prices were $20.92 vs. $18.57 in the first quarter of last year and natural gas prices were $2.75 per thousand cubic feet vs. $2.16.

Mobil said worldwide refining and marketing operating earnings fell $90 million to $150 million as its U.S. operations lost $42 million due to shutdowns at four of its five refineries for maintenance.
Mobil said it had a record quarter in worldwide exploration and production with a $182 million rise in operating earnings to $694 million.
Chemical earnings rose to $85 million from $70 million a year earlier due to stronger sales of polyethylene and paraxylene.
Mobil's stock was off 12.5 cents at $125.75 on the New York Stock Exchange in afternoon trading.
San Francisco-based Chevron said its earnings jumped 35 percent to $831 million, or $1.27 a share, in the first quarter from $616 million, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenues were up 8 percent at $11.1 billion vs. $10.3 billion.

"Our upstream operations turned in excellent results. Crude oil and natural gas prices on average were higher than a year ago, although they have fallen significantly from year-end 1996 levels," said Chairman Ken Derr.
"The declining oil and gas prices during the quarter benefited our U.S. downstream and chemicals businesses, as lower feedstock and fuel costs improved product sales margins," he said.
Derr said oil prices have continued to soften in the second quarter. Chevron's stock was 12.5 cents lower at $66.50 on the NYSE.

Phillips Petroleum said its first quarter earnings sank to $227 million, or 86 cents a share, against year ago earnings of $695 million or $2.65 a share. The year ago earnings included a $565 million tax benefit.
Revenues rose to $3.99 billion from $3.60 billion.
The Bartlesville, Okla.-based oil company said higher crude oil and natural gas prices offset a 4 percent drop in production worldwide.
Phillips stock was unchanged at $38.50 on the NYSE.

Conoco said its earnings for the first quarter jumped 55 percent to $331 million vs. year earlier earnings of $214 million on revenues of $5.4 billion against $4.7 billion. The company, a unit of DuPont Co., does not report per share earnings.
